Want to improve conditions on the border? Start there.

@CBP mission is tough as is. They’re being asked to do more than they are able to handle while also handling a spike in crossings at the border & they’re being hampered in their ability to do so by an arbitrary cap on detention beds & an effort to continue to lower that number.
and toothbrushes. pic.twitter.com/bxjPI025g9
hygiene supplies, pic.twitter.com/L0UuqVif3c
provide clean clothing, pic.twitter.com/1SEcqdRidt
or do laundry, pic.twitter.com/OdJkqqmenT
If they can't be moved to @ICEgov facilities due to lack of funding or space, they have to do best with what they have, especially to care for children. pic.twitter.com/jRsghJkBXI
@CBP wasn't meant to house folks or process them into the US/return them to their home country if they don't have legal justification for being here.

Here's the problem with that: the need to process still exists. But if @ICEgov can’t do their job as intended, it falls to @CBP to do it. So rather than @CBP’s specific mission to be law enforcement on the border, they now are doing their job AND @ICEgov’s job of detention.
But recently there has been an effort by Democrats to limit the amount of beds available.

That bed is an important part of the conversation–@ICEgov receives funding for that mission by the bed. The amount of money is connected to the number of beds it has–and that’s how many people it can have in its facility at any given time.

For others, law enforcement is waiting on their criminal history from their home country. @ICEgov facilities should be the primary place they received medical care, additional resources, and a bed to sleep in.

Under current law, when an adult or family unit is caught by @CBP, they should be processed in the facility and then transferred to @ICEgov while more information came in. If that individual makes an asylum claim, they do so w/ @CBP.
Unaccompanied minors are still coming across, but so are family units who stay together while they are processed. More space is needed for @CBP to conduct its mission.
@CBP mission is to process people coming across the border through non-approved channels (i.e., without a passport, a visa, or a legal reason to be present).
But an important part of the story is that this was always supposed to be a short-term facility before unaccompanied minors could be put in the care of @HHSGov or returned to their home country.
The facility is divided up using chain link fence–you can see what it looks like in the background here. pic.twitter.com/tGS6Mp4zc0

Sunday I visited a @CBP facility that’s gotten a lot of attention for being a place where people are held in “cages.” This facility was built in 2014. At that time, there was a spike in unaccompanied minors, mostly teenagers, crossing the southern border.
pic.twitter.com/d0pZbcQulG

Currently, you send your hard-earned $'s to DC & never really know how they are used/where they end up going. My bill, The Taxpayers Right to Know Act, is a bipartisan bill requiring the federal gov’t to make public the details, costs, & assessments related to all fed programs.
Do you know where you can go to see how your taxpayer dollars are spent?
..of border patrol to do their job. As the report makes clear, the process is broken at every step. The longer we delay fixing these issues, the more children are put in harms way.

That's a huge issue that needs a solution. And in the meantime, we need to curb the flow of family units, which starts with fixing the anti-human trafficking legislation and the Flores Settlement Agreement - A decades old court settlement that hampers the ability..

Because the crisis continues to change and get worse, the preliminary report couldn’t address all of the growing issues, such as what to do about the growing population of 17 year old males crossing the border.
